string-array.item: Coffee was discovered in Ethiopia around the 9th century, according to the legend of the shepherd Kaldi.
Kaldi noticed that his goats became more active after eating the fruits of the coffee plant.
The word \'coffee\' comes from the Arabic \'qahwa\', which originally meant \'wine\'.
Coffee arrived in Europe in the 17th century and quickly became a popular drink.
Venice was one of the first European cities to open a coffeehouse in 1645.
The first English coffeehouse opened in Oxford in 1650, known as \'The Angel\'.
Coffee was banned in Mecca in 1511 for being considered stimulating and suspicious.
In 1675, King Charles II of England attempted to close coffeehouses for encouraging political debates.
Coffee became popular in America after the Boston Tea Party in 1773, when tea was boycotted.
The first coffeehouse in the United States opened in Boston in 1676.
Instant coffee was invented by the Japanese Satori Kato in 1901.
Caffeine was first isolated in 1819 by German chemist Friedlieb Runge.
It was Goethe who suggested that Runge study coffee beans.
Espresso was invented in Italy at the beginning of the 20th century.
Luigi Bezzera patented the first espresso machine in 1901.
The Italian moka pot was created by Alfonso Bialetti in 1933.
Cappuccino gets its name from the Capuchin monks, due to the color of their habit.
Brazil has been the largest coffee producer in the world for more than 150 years.
Colombia is one of the largest exporters of Arabica coffee in the world.
Arabica coffee represents approximately 60% of global production.
Robusta coffee contains nearly twice as much caffeine as Arabica.
Decaffeinated coffee is produced by extracting caffeine with water or natural solvents.
Caffeine works by blocking adenosine, a neurotransmitter that induces sleep.
The stimulating effect of coffee usually lasts between 3 and 5 hours.
Coffee was Napoleon Bonaparte\'s preferred drink.
Honoré de Balzac drank between 40 and 50 cups of coffee a day while writing.
Voltaire drank more than 30 cups of coffee daily and said it kept him lucid.
Beethoven counted exactly 60 coffee beans per cup before brewing it.
Composer Johann Sebastian Bach wrote a cantata dedicated to coffee in 1732.
Bach’s so-called \'Coffee Cantata\' jokes about his daughter\'s addiction to the drink.
Finland consumes more coffee per capita than any other country in the world.
The average Finn consumes more than 12 kilograms of coffee per year.
Italy has one of the world’s most influential coffee cultures, centered on espresso.
In Ethiopia, coffee is considered a symbol of hospitality and respect.
Coffee arrived in South America for the first time through French Guiana in the 18th century.
Coffee was a luxury drink in Europe until the 18th century.
In the 19th century, coffee became a basic product of international trade.
Coffee beans are actually the seeds of the coffee fruit, called \'cherries\'.
Each coffee cherry usually contains two beans, although some contain only one (peaberry).
Green coffee must be roasted before being ground and brewed.
The roast level affects the flavor, aroma, and acidity of the coffee.
The most expensive coffee in the world is Kopi Luwak, produced from beans digested by civets.
Kopi Luwak originated in Indonesia and can reach prices of more than 500 euros per kilo.
Turkish coffee has been an Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity since 2013.
In Turkey, preparing coffee is a symbolic act of friendship and hospitality.
In Vienna, traditional coffeehouses were declared cultural heritage by UNESCO in 2011.
Espresso literally means \'express\' or \'under pressure\' in Italian.
Americano coffee emerged during World War II, when soldiers diluted espresso with water.
The latte became popular in the United States in the 1980s thanks to the rise of Starbucks.
The Flat White originated in Australia or New Zealand (its exact origin is still debated).
The first capsule coffee machine was patented by Nestlé in 1986.
Caffeine is the most widely consumed psychoactive stimulant in the world.
An espresso contains less caffeine than a cup of filtered coffee, but it is more concentrated.
Coffee can improve physical performance by increasing adrenaline release.
Studies show that coffee reduces the risk of diseases such as Parkinson’s or type 2 diabetes.
Drinking coffee in moderation is associated with longer life expectancy.
The aroma of coffee comes from more than 800 different volatile compounds.
Coffee has more antioxidants than most fruits and vegetables.
In Japan, there are cafés where you can drink coffee alongside cats, owls, or even snakes.
South Korea has more coffee shops per capita than any other country in the world.
Coffee was introduced to Yemen in the 15th century, where it was exported from the port of Mocha.
The term \'mocha\' comes from the Yemeni port of Mocha, famous for its coffee.
The first coffeehouse in Paris opened in 1686, called Café Procope.
Voltaire, Rousseau, and Diderot frequented Café Procope.
Coffee helped drive the Enlightenment by serving as a meeting point for thinkers.
In the 18th century, coffeehouses in England were known as \'penny universities\'.
They were called this because for a penny you could buy a cup of coffee and converse with intellectuals.
The first modern espresso machine was developed by Achille Gaggia in 1947.
Gaggia introduced the lever system, which produced the characteristic espresso crema.
A barista is a professional specialized in the preparation and presentation of coffee.
The term \'barista\' comes from Italian and means \'barman\'.
International Coffee Day is celebrated on October 1st.
Coffee is the second most traded commodity in the world, after oil.
More than 25 million people work directly or indirectly in the coffee industry.
A single coffee tree can produce between 1 and 2 kilograms of beans per year.
Coffee trees can live more than 50 years under proper conditions.
Coffee grows best in tropical regions at altitudes between 800 and 2000 meters.
The coffee-growing region of Colombia was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 2011.
In Ethiopia, coffee is part of daily social and family ceremonies.
Ethiopians often roast, grind, and prepare the coffee in front of guests.
In Sweden, there is a tradition called \'fika\', a daily break to drink coffee and socialize.
Scandinavians consider coffee an essential part of their work culture.
Coffee contains small amounts of vitamins B2, B3, B5, and minerals such as magnesium and potassium.
Caffeine begins to take effect about 15 minutes after consumption.
Coffee has a pH between 4.5 and 6, making it slightly acidic.
The first paper coffee filters were invented by Melitta Bentz in 1908.
Melitta Bentz created her filter using blotting paper and a perforated can.
The company Melitta remains one of the main producers of coffee filters.
Irish coffee was invented in the 1940s at Foynes Airport in Ireland.
It was created by chef Joe Sheridan, who added Irish whiskey to the drink to warm travelers.
Cold brew coffee became popular in Japan centuries before it arrived in the West.
Cold brew is made with cold water and left to steep for 12 to 24 hours.
Modern baristas compete in world latte art championships.
Latte art was born in Seattle in the 1980s.
The first World Barista Championship was held in 1991.
Coffee plays a central role in the culture of many countries, from Italy to Ethiopia.
NASA developed a special cup for drinking coffee in space.
The first coffee consumed in space was in 1969 by astronaut Buzz Aldrin.
In 2015, astronauts on the International Space Station enjoyed the first espresso made in orbit.
That machine was designed by Lavazza and the Italian Space Agency.
Coffee has more than 120 known species, although only two are grown commercially: Arabica and Robusta.
Coffee first arrived in Japan in the 17th century, but did not become popular until after World War II.
In Ethiopia, the coffee ceremony can last more than an hour and includes three rounds of serving.
Coffee arrived in Brazil in 1727 thanks to Francisco de Melo Palheta, who smuggled seeds from French Guiana.
Coffee was brought to Hawaii in 1825, establishing the famous Kona growing region.
Instant coffee was popularized by Nestlé during World War II under the brand Nescafé.
The first automatic home espresso machine was launched by Gaggia in 1977.
Coffee was considered a medicine in Europe during the 16th century.
In the 18th century, Frederick the Great of Prussia tried to ban coffee to promote beer consumption.
Green coffee was used as a currency of exchange in Africa for centuries.
Coffee is Ethiopia’s most important commercial crop, representing more than 30% of its exports.
The first canned coffee was launched in Japan in 1969 by UCC Ueshima Coffee Co.
In Italy, drinking coffee at the bar is cheaper than sitting at a table.
Coffee arrived in Mexico at the end of the 18th century and quickly spread through Chiapas and Veracruz.
Jamaica Blue Mountain coffee is one of the most prized and mildest in the world.
In the 17th century, some European clerics tried to ban coffee, calling it the \'devil’s drink\'.
Pope Clement VIII approved coffee consumption in 1600, declaring it \'so delicious that it must be baptized\'.
In Yemen, coffee was considered an aid for meditation among Sufi monks.
The term \'coffee break\' became popular in the United States in the 1950s thanks to advertising campaigns.
Instant coffee became essential during World War I because of its practicality for soldiers.
80% of the coffee consumed in the world is Arabica.
In France, philosopher Montesquieu often wrote accompanied by several cups of coffee.
Specialty coffee is defined as scoring above 80 points on the SCA scale.
Ethiopian Yirgacheffe coffee is famous for its floral and citrus notes.
Coffee was introduced to India by the Sufi Baba Budan in the 17th century.
Coffee is the main source of antioxidants in the average Western diet.
An average cup of coffee contains between 80 and 120 mg of caffeine.
Black coffee without sugar contains only about 2 calories per cup.
The Guinness World Record for most cups of coffee served in one day is over 12,000, achieved in Colombia.
Roasted coffee releases carbon dioxide for several days, which is why it must rest before being packaged.
Coffees grown at higher altitudes tend to have more complex flavors and brighter acidity.
